text: Thanks for all the help everyone, I think I decided to switch over to GoLang for learning. It seems to hit a sweet spot between developer ease, and performance. Eventually I may go back to trying to learn Rust - but, its just extremely difficult for me to learn.

elements.text: Thanks for all the help everyone, I think I decided to switch over to GoLang for learning. It seems to hit a sweet spot between developer ease, and performance. Eventually I may go back to trying to learn Rust - but, its just extremely difficult for me to learn.

text: You're welcome. It is a decision many have made before.. I do think though, that you'll be back. There are so many reasons to stay with Rust, even if it has this ruthless correctness-thing.. But that's unimportant for now.

elements.text: You're welcome. It is a decision many have made before.. I do think though, that you'll be back. There are so many reasons to stay with Rust, even if it has this ruthless correctness-thing.. But that's unimportant for now.

text: well ... it's part of the trifecta ... <https://youtu.be/6qCH7Y2rc_w>

attachments.title: Rust, Julia, and Go: Disruptive New Programming Languages Changing the Face of Computing
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Rust, Julia, and Go: Disruptive New Programming Languages Changing the Face of Computing
attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/6qCH7Y2rc_w?feature=oembed&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

elements.text: well ... it's part of the trifecta ...

text: It's just that.. Learning systems programming seems very hard.. And Rust facilitates that learning the best. I have a code-base that I wrote before I knew a bunch of things, and even though there are bad things in it, I feel safe in that it runs, and refactoring it won't be that difficult.. My point is: Go makes compromises, that while you're learning, you probably don't have a feeling for these compromises, but with Rust, they are just right there.. Completely explicit.

elements.text: It's just that.. Learning systems programming seems very hard.. And Rust facilitates that learning the best. I have a code-base that I wrote before I knew a bunch of things, and even though there are bad things in it, I feel safe in that it runs, and refactoring it won't be that difficult.. My point is: Go makes compromises, that while you're learning, you probably don't have a feeling for these compromises, but with Rust, they are just right there.. Completely explicit.

text: Yea I think that's the battle. I love what Rust promises, but I need tools that let me prototype pretty rapidly. Over time I'll get there. I don't have a CS background so it's exponentially harder for me to learn. I can write C++ but - I'm nowhere near a pro. A colleague once told me he'd been writing C++ for 10 years and that, he was a bottom of the barrel programmer(he could do some crazy stuff). So with Systems, it's just another ballgame

text: For prototyping quickly.. you have Julia, right? That's what I'm hoping for atleast.

elements.text: For prototyping quickly.. you have Julia, right? That's what I'm hoping for atleast.

text: Yea I have Julia, but Julia craps out as soon as you need a front end, or some boiler plate application programming.

elements.text: Yea I have Julia, but Julia craps out as soon as you need a front end, or some boiler plate application programming.

text: so I am hoping for 2 tools. One for the heavy mathy stuff, and one for the app stuff.

elements.text: so I am hoping for 2 tools. One for the heavy mathy stuff, and one for the app stuff.

text: <@UUCN877U5> that's the point of Julia, right? that you can prototype AND deploy ...

elements.text: that's the point of Julia, right? that you can prototype AND deploy ...

text: you can deploy but,, not for embedded applications, or desktop applications(like yes you can but my experiences are beyond subsatisfactory).

text: we need to have a way to generate standalone applications. And I don't think that PackageCompiler will help with that in it's current state

attachments.fallback: [December 17th, 2020 10:24 AM] arikatzpro: I think Julia has potential for lower level type stuff. Multiple team members, including keno and jeff have discussed intentions and possibilities for static typing, Julian is already working on static binary generation with a lighter runtime or even no runtime for subsets of julia features, and Just today on the ML call keno discussed static memory management refcounting

text: I can't think of any benefits to learning Golang other then in the case where it's a specific job requirement, there are dozens of more interesting learning languages, Rust included

text:
Julia will have it, but it's going to take a while is my guess. I'd love to be pleasantly surprised. But they said roughly 6 months or so. And it might be very researchy at that point. Maybe 1.7?

I think golang is pretty nice. It has decent packages, it's own cross platform GUI situation, can run embedded(tinygo, etc), has a decent bit of safety built into it. Not as fast as C++, but way easier to scale out concurrent tasks with, and at least faster than python.

elements.text:
